bibl.title: Eastman Kodak Radio Program #6: Yellow Jack, by Howard W. Haggard, September 27, 1931

div1.p: This script briefly covers major historical accounts of yellow fever including stories of the Flying Dutchman, the Philadelphia epidemic, and the building of the Panama Canal. The document also addresses the heroic experiments performed on human volunteers to discover that mosquitoes transmitted yellow fever. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Eastman Kodak Radio Program #6: Yellow Jack, by Howard W. Haggard, September 27, 1931
div1.p:
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
Sept. 11, 1931

Eastman Kodak Radio
Program #36
September 27, 1931
Dr Howard W. Haggard

And do you remember the legend of the Flying Dutchman,
the specter ship that haunted the waters off the Cape of Good
Hope? Silently it glided by in the night, without lights,
without helmsmen, with sails blown full, a ship that went on
and on but never made a port. The sailors who saw it passing
in the moonlight, an apparition on the silent sea, were struck
with terror, for the Flying Dutchman was an omen of disaster.
On that phantom ship, so the story says, a murder had been
committed, and as a retribution Yellow Jack had broken out on
board, making the ship a pariah of the sea, about which grew
legends and superstitions.

The story of the Flying Dutchman was the sailor's
picturesque way of expressing his fear of Yellow Jack, the yellow
fever. There are true cases of such ill-omened ships, but most
did not sail the high seas as phantoms; they lay rotting in the
waters, shunned by the sailors. But some there were that put
out to sea; thus there was the barque Huskisson which in 1837
came in to Sierra Leone, West Africa. While she was unloading,
I wrote Dr. Haggard Sept. 24/1931.
ref. p. 10.
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-2-
yellow fever broke out among the crew. All but three died.
The disease, the dreaded Yellow Jack, spread to the colony on
shore. For three months the Huskisson lay in the harbor without
a man on board. Then when all danger from the disease seemed
passed, a new crew was finally formed. Every man among them
trembled when he went on board; such was the strength of their
superstitious belief in the haunting yellow fever. But they were
tempted there by premises of high pay.

Three days passed; the ship put out to sea; all was
well on board. True, there was a host of ravenous mosquitoes
stirred up from the bilge, making the nights unhappy, but who
minded mosquitoes when the pay was high? Some of the sailors
spoke lightly of their former fears; but the more pessimistic
ones said, “Wait; she's haunted with Yellow Jack!” On the fourth
day a sailor lay in his bunk tossing with the fever - then
another was stricken, and another. Yellow Jack had come. The
sails were down, the ship drifted in the current, all of the
crew save one or two were dead. The barque was another Flying
Dutchman, every port closed to her.

The yellow fever was a mysterious disease. That was
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-3-
why it brought such fear and panic to men. For three months
and longer it lay in wait on an empty ship to exterminate the
crew that came aboard. There was no contact there with men
who had the disease; its ways were mysterious, and from its
mystery grew the fear of it.

Just one fact, one item of medical knowledge, was
needed to show the way in bringing the disease under control.
If someone had only told those sailors on the barque Huskisson
that the mosquitoes that infested the ship were the source of
the infection, it would not have become a companion of the
Flying Dutchman. A few yards of mosquito cloth, a few pounds
of sulphur to burn, and the ship would have been free from
Yellow Jack, But that knowledge did not come for sixty-three
years - just at the turn of the present century.

When did yellow fever start? No one knows; probably
it had a foothold from time immemorial in the islands of the
West Indies and on the mainland shores near them. But I don't
believe the natives suffered much from the disease in these
districts where it had always been present. In childhood,
when they must, of necessity, have contracted it, yellow fever
is usually mild and one attack confers life-long immunity.
And so, long before Europeans came to the New World, the disease ?
?
It came from Africa brought probably in the
slave trade
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-4-
and the natives had struck a sort of compromise, a balance.
The disease flourished, and the children had it; most of
them survived, never to be affected again. But, following
Columbus, the coming of the Spaniards, the Portugese, the
French, the Dutch, and the English, the balance was upset.
Here were adults who had not had yellow fever in childhood.
For such adults yellow fever was not a mild disease; in its
outbreak it killed forty, fifty, and sometimes ninety percent
of the immigrants to the New World islands. Yellow fever
became the disease of the Conquistadores. Their graves, some
marked, but more unmarked, dot the islands.

The new arrivals to the Western Hemisphere upset
another balance that had been reached with the disease; they
introduced commerce. The mosquitoes which cause the disease
do not fly over long distances, but they do ride on ships.
Yellow fever boarded the ships of the buccaneers. It followed
the lines of the slave trade tofrom West Africa. It spread to
Spain, Portugal, Italy, and France, and once to England. It
traveled along the eastern coast of North America to Philadelphia,
New York, and Boston.

If, even for a moment, you doubt the indispensability
of medical science to the spread of civilization and to commerce,
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-5-
just imagine yourself in Philadelphia in the summer of 1793.
Commerce had developed then, but the medical control of yellow
fever had not. The infected mosquitoes had been imported into
Philadelphia. Here is part of a contemporaneous account of the
epidemic that killed in that summer ten percent of the city's
population.

“The consternation of the people of Philadelphia at
that period was beyond all bounds. Dismay and affright were
visible on the countenances of almost every person. Of those
who remained, many shut themselves in their houses and were afraid
to walk the streets ... The corpses of the most respectable
citizens, even those who did not die of the epidemic, were carried
to the grave on the shafts of a chaise, the horse driven by a
negro, unattended by friends or relatives and without any sort of
ceremony. People hastily shifted their course at the sight of a
hearse coming toward them. Many never walked on the footpaths,
but went into the middle of the street to avoid passing by houses
wherein people had died. Acquaintances and friends avoided one
another in the street and only signified their regard by a cold nod.
The old custom of shaking hands fell into such disuse that many
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-6-
shrank back with affright at even the offer of the hand. A
person with crepe or any appearance of mourning was shunned
like a viper, and many prided themselves highly on the skill
and address with which they got to the windward of every person
they met. Indeed, it is not probable that London, at the last
stage of the Plague, exhibited stronger marks of terror than
were seen in Philadelphia from the 24th or 25th of April until
pretty late in September. While affairs were in this deplorable
stage and the people at the lowest ebb of despair, we cannot be
astonished at the frightful scenes that were enacted, which seemed
to indicate a total dissolution of the bonds of society in the
nearest and dearest connections. Who, without horror, can reflect }
on a husband deserting his wife in the last agony; a wife who had }
been united to him perhaps for twenty years, a wife unfeelingly }?
abandoning her husband on his deathbed; parents forsaking their }
only child without remorse; children ungratefully flying from their }
parents and resigning them to chance, without an inquiry after
their health or safety .....?”

p.hi: MEDICAL KNOWLEDGE BRINGS FREEDOM FROM DISEASE

div1.p:
That was the state of Philadelphia when Yellow Jack
swooped down upon it. Such occasional epidemics in temperate
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-7-
regions always died out as did this one in Philadelphia, “pretty
late in September” with the coming of frost and cold weather.
The reason was then obscure; but now we know that freezing weather
put an end to the mosquitoes which were carrying the infection.

Thus in bygone days there were occasional outbreaks of
yellow fever in northern regions, but in the areas to which the
fever-bearing mosquitoes were indigenous there was a more or less
constant occurrence of the disease. And what a toll it took of
the white immigrants there. The successive British garrisons in
Jamaica and Bermuda were from time to time almost exterminated.
The mortality among those sturdy colonists and soldiers sent out
from England was tremendous. For years in Jamaica the annual
death rate in the garrison was nearly two hundred in a thousand -
one in every five - each year. Do you remember in Thackeray's
Vanity Fair the unfortunate Rawdon Crawley who is sent as governor
to “Coventry Island” in the West Indies and is not expected to
last long?

It seems almost incredible, doesn't it, that these
islands which are now health and pleasure resorts were until thirty
years ago almost the unhealthiest places in the world for a tourist?
And the whole transformation was brought about by just one medical
discovery which gave us this bit of knowledge: yellow fever is
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-8-
carried by a certain variety of mosquito and can be abolished
by exterminating the mosquito. Moreover, this particular
mosquito is an easy one to exterminate. It breeds near houses
in water barrels, upturned tin cans, and sagging gutters that
collect rain water. Clean up about the home, screen the rain
barrels, oil a few ponds, keep the sick under mesh so that
no mosquitoes can reach them to acquire infection, and almost
like magic a scourge of the tropics disappears.

I have often said in my talks here that modern civi-
lization as we know it is made possible only by modern medical
knowledge. There is no more striking proof of this fact than
the story of the building of the Panama Canal. That was less an
engineering feat than a medical one. The isthmus was the “white
man's grave.” Yellow Fever stalked there as a pestilence, and
except for it the Panama Canal would belong to another nation.
A French company under the guidance of the famous Ferdinand de
Lessep who built the Suez Canal obtained a concession in Panama
and started actively on the construction of the canal in the
latter part of the nineteenth century. It is hard to say whether
the greatest difficulty of the company was financial, structural,
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-9-
or medical. The canal was not completed, and there is a legend
that says that there is a Frenchman buried under every tie of the
railroad built. Certainly the mortality from yellow fever was
appalling, and even if the canal had been built after immense
loss of life and yellow fever not brought under control, ships
would still go round Cape Horn instead of taking the shorter
route thru Panama; if yellow fever still existed there, the ports
of the world would of necessity impose an absolute quarantine on
all ships which had passed thru the canal.

One bit of medical information made it possible for
the United States to build the Panama Canal. The sanitary work
in the isthmus carried out by General Gorgas wiped out yellow
fever in the canal zone; it made it the healthiest strip of land
in all the tropics. The one bit of medical knowledge upon which
this stupendous piece of work was based was that of how yellow
fever is transmitted.

To the people of the United States there is a particular
pride in that knowledge of far reaching effect. It was obtained by
the men in the medical corps of our army. They found a way to
control yellow fever; and in the search they willingly risked and
gave their lives that men might be free from this scourge.

J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-10-

In 1898 Cuba was the center of war activity; the
battleship Maine had been sunk; troops were landing - more of
them to die by yellow fever than by the bullets of the Spaniards.
After the war troops were garrisoned in Havana; yellow fever
continued. The city was scrubbed; every corner was tidied up,
but the disease grew in volume. In Havana there were three times
as many deaths from yellow fever in 1900 as there were in 1899.
The situation was critical. A Yellow Fever Commission was ap-
pointed. Doctor Walter Reed headed it, and with him were Doctors
James Carrol, Jesse Lazear, and Aristides Agramote. In July this
group of men started a war - a war on yellow fever - that in its
far-reaching effects dwarfed to insignificance the battles that
had liberated Cuba. The war headed by Major Walter Reed freed men
from yellow fever. In six months Jesse Lazear was dead of the
disease, James Carrol had had it and recovered; (a dozen or) no more ?
volunteers had given their lives in experiments; but Walter Reed
and the other survivors of the Yellow Fever Commission had learned
how to control yellow fever. In 1902 Havana for the first time in
a hundred and fifty years was free from yellow fever.
Lazear was the only casualty
in these experiments.

The experiments that the Commission carried out had their
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-11-
starting point from a statement made by Doctor Carlos Finlay
of Havana. He had said repeatedly that yellow fever was
carried by mosquitoes, but he had no proofs that carried
conviction. It was merely his theory, and every one else had
a theory - each one different. But to Walter Reed Doctor
Finlay's suggestion seemed plausible; the Commission decided
to test it. The experiments had to be on men. Let a mosquito
bite a patient with yellow fever and then let it bite a well
man. If he got yellow fever, then there was something in the
theory. Sounds simple, doesn't it? But how would you like to
be the man whom the mosquito bit? What sort of thoughts would
go thru your mind as you stood there waiting with the mosquito
on your arm swelling up with your blood? There was no excitement
of battle, just standing there watching a mosquito who had bitten
a man dying of yellow fever and was now biting you. If the ex-
periment were a success, your chances of living or dying were just
about even. James Carrol tried it; he lived, but it was a close
call; for days he lay stricken with yellow fever. Jesse Lazear
tried it with a stray mosquito that flew across the yellow fever
ward. He died.

Then there were experiments, dozens of them, carried
out on volunteers. These men who offered their lives for the
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-12-
work stayed for weeks as prisoners in mosquito-proof huts to
make certain that they were not already infected with yellow
fever. Then infected mosquitoes were turned loose in their huts.
All got yellow fever, and somebut none died.

There was no question now but that the mosquito carried
the disease. But that was not the only proof needed. It must be
shown that the disease was carried only by the mosquito. And so
new volunteers took their places in the screened huts. A week or
two they waited to show they were not infected with yellow fever,
and then their beds were made with gruesome linen. Night after
night they slept on soiled clothing taken from beds on which men
had died of yellow fever - horrid duty, but a safe one, so it
proved, for none of these volunteers came down with yellow fever.

p.hi: NO GREATER DEEDS CAN ANY MEN DO

div1.p:
No mosquitoes - no yellow fever. Just one bit of medical
information needed to free our American continents from a disease,
a horrible disease. Thousands upon thousands of lives have been
saved, the canal built, the West Indies made safe, New Orleans freed
from fever, and the northern cities spared of occasional devastating
epidemics. Great accomplishments these - almost too big to be com-
prehended in their entirety. Perhaps that's why my thoughts turn
J. WALTER THOMPSON COMPANY
-13-
instead to that little group of men in Cuba, the volunteers
who let the mosquitoes bite them to find out how yellow fever
was carried. My thoughts turn, too, to the great Hideyo Nogutchi
and Adrian Stokes who only three years ago on the West Coast of
Africa gave their lives in learning more about the yellow fever
that still thrives there.

These are very human things; we can comprehend and pay
our tribute to such bravery and self-sacrifice. War has it heroes,
religion its saints and martyrs, and so also has medicine. These
heroes, saints, and martyrs of medicine work and fight and die,
often in obscurity, that their fellow men may be freed from disease
and suffering and sorrow. No greater deeds can any men do.
